repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
The benefit of this is that users only pay for what they use. If e.g.
only `vim.lsp.buf_get_clients()` is called then they don't need to load
all modules under `vim.lsp` which could lead to significant startuptime
saving.

Also `vim.lsp.module` is a bit nicer to user compared to
`require("vim.lsp.module")`.

This isn't used for some nested modules such as `filetype` as it breaks
tests with error messages such as "attempt to index field 'detect'".
It's not entirely certain the reason for this, but it is likely it is
due to filetype being precompiled which would imply deferred loading
isn't needed for performance reasons.

comment_data.body: this block negates most of the effects of `_dunderload_submodules`. Is that intentional?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,24 +7,39 @@ local tbl_isempty, tbl_extend = vim.tbl_isempty, vim.tbl_extend
 local validate = vim.validate
 local if_nil = vim.F.if_nil
 
-local lsp = {
-  protocol = protocol,
-
-  handlers = default_handlers,
+local submodules = {
+  '_changetracking',
+  '_completion',
+  '_dynamic',
+  'buf',
+  'codelens',
+  'diagnostic',
+  'handlers',
+  'inlay_hint',
+  'log',
+  'protocol',
+  'rpc',
+  'semantic_tokens',
+  'tagfunc',
+  'util',
+}
+local dundarload_submodules = vim._dundarload_submodules('vim.lsp', submodules)
+local lsp = setmetatable({}, dundarload_submodules)
 
-  buf = require('vim.lsp.buf'),
-  diagnostic = require('vim.lsp.diagnostic'),
-  codelens = require('vim.lsp.codelens'),
-  inlay_hint = require('vim.lsp.inlay_hint'),
-  semantic_tokens = semantic_tokens,
-  util = util,
+local default_handlers = lsp.handlers
+local log = lsp.log
+local lsp_rpc = lsp.rpc
+local protocol = lsp.protocol
+local ms = protocol.Methods
+local util = lsp.util
+local changetracking = lsp._changetracking
+local semantic_tokens = lsp.semantic_tokens

comment_data.body:
What do you think if we mangled this to something like:

```lua
--- @generic T
--- @param root string
--- @param _mod T
--- @return T
local function dundarload_modules(root, _mod)
  return setmetatable({}, {
    __index = function(t, k)
      t[k] = require(string.format('%s.%s', root, k))
      return t[k]
    end
  })
end

local lsp = dundarload_modules('vim.lsp', {
  _changetracking = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp._changetracking'
  _completion = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp._completion'
  _dynamic = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp._dynamic'
  buf = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.buf'
  codelens = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.codelens'
  diagnostic = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.diagnostic'
  handlers = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.handlers'
  inlay_hint = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.inlay_hint'
  log = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.log'
  protocol = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.protocol'
  rpc = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.rpc'
  semantic_tokens = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.semantic_tokens'
  tagfunc = ..., --- @module 'vim.lsp.tagfunc'
  util = ... --- @module 'vim.lsp.util'
})
```

or is that going too far?

comment_data.body: This is a class rather than a module, so should remain as `LanguageTree` (the module returns class itself). We can consider `vim.treesitter.languagetree` returns a table `M = { LanguageTree = ... }` instead.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    ---@param t table<string, any>
    ---@param k string
    __index = function(t, k)
      if not _mod[k] then
        return nil
      end
      local modname = string.format('%s.%s', root, k)
      ---@type boolean, any
      local ok, ret = pcall(require, modname)
```


* `vim.treesitter.submodule_that_does_not_exist` should return nil (without errors)

* `vim.treesitter.submodule_to_defer_load` should (re-)throw errors if an error would be thrown on `require`-ing that module.

In order to make this possible, we'll need to change the "deferload" declaration as:

```diff
 local M = vim._deferload_submodules('vim.treesitter', {
-  _fold = ..., --- @module 'vim.treesitter._fold'
+  _fold = { ... }, --- @module 'vim.treesitter._fold'
```

because `...` evaluates to `nil` in Lua. The table `_mod` is currently not used, but can be used to determine which submodule is registered to be lazy-loaded.

I also suggest we should add a test in `test/functional/lua/vim_spec.lua` to test and ensure the behavior.

+      local ok, ret = pcall(require, string.format('%s.%s', root, k))

comment_data.body:
> I don't think we need to encase the modules in tables to do this.

Hmm you're right. When require-ing the module, `...` evaluates to the name of the module (e.g. the `"vim.treesitter"` string), *not `nil`*. (Maybe I did something wrong when I was testing this out yesterday...!?) Sorry about making a confusion here.

comment_regular_data.body: LSP (lua-ls) will not like this due to its dynamic nature --- type inference and resolving LSP definition/references are broken.
We can use `--- @module 'vim.lsp.module'` to overcome that in places. But yes, we should be mindful where/how we apply this.

This is generalizing/lifting a common, existing pattern, right? Would be helpful to mention that in the commit message.

> LSP (lua-ls) will not like this due to its dynamic nature ...
>> We can use `--- @module 'vim.lsp.module'` to overcome that in places. But yes, we should be mindful where/how we apply this.

Does that mean we shouldn't apply it to "all" of `vim.**` ? Ideally, the loading behavior of all `vim.**` would follow one rule.

> This is generalizing/lifting a common, existing pattern, right?

Eh? I don't know about that. I've used this on `lsp.lua`, `treesitter.lua`, `provider.lua` and `filetype.lua`. Only `treesitter.lua` used this before. So not that common.

> It looks like this breaks `vim.lsp.noexist` which should return `nil` and not error.

Why is it obvious it should return nil? It is a require after all which does error if it doesn't exist.

> ... is used to initialize modules instead of nil as it's an
undocumented hack to make luals type annotations work correctly. This
value may be changed in the future if luals comes up with a better way
to do this.

I think this is highly unlikely. `...` should always have type `...any`.

> I don't think it's obvious why it should return nil. It is a require after all which does error if it doesn't exist.

The require is an implementation detail. This should not be exposed to users, otherwise this isn't a refactor.

> The require is an implementation detail. This should not be exposed to users.

You mean it *should* act as "normal" table even if it uses `require` under the hood? Hmmm, I guess that's a fair point since it is used as a normal table so maybe the expectation is that it should act as one as well. Alright, I'll change it.

> I think this is highly unlikely. `...` should always have type `...any`.

What do you mean by "should"? As in you personally believe this is the correct behavior?

Also I don't think `...any` is a type. Luals doesn't recognize it at least.

> ... is used to initialize modules instead of nil as it's an
undocumented hack to make luals type annotations work correctly. This
value may be changed in the future if luals comes up with a better way
to do this.

For the record: I searched the documentation and this behavior is *documented*: https://www.lua.org/manual/5.1/manual.html#pdf-require

> To find a loader, require is guided by the [package.loaders](https://www.lua.org/manual/5.1/manual.html#pdf-package.loaders) array.
> Once a loader is found, require calls the loader with **a single argument, modname**

So under the hood, `require('vim.treesitter')` works like:
```lua
local loader = loadfile("$VIMRUNTIME/vim/treesitter.lua")  ---@type fun(...): any
return loader("vim.treesitter")  -- calls the loader with a single argument, "modname"
```
therefore the *varargs* `...` in the module context evaluates to the modname, e.g. `"vim.treesitter"` during runtime.

For Lua-LS, since `...` represents a vararg expression as per the language specification (https://www.lua.org/manual/5.1/manual.html#2.5), Lua-LS *should* resolve the type for `...` as `any` (it can't be `nil` because `...` may not be `nil`), or more precisely "variadic `any`" (returning multiple values). If it were other (concrete) type, it can be invalid typing. So I don't think this is a hack; and LuaLS will also not change its behavior (about typing) in the future. Typing could break (but unlikely), but at least the runtime behavior is guaranteed.

> therefore the varargs ... in the module context evaluates to the modname, e.g. "vim.treesitter" during runtime.

It's resolved during *runtime*? That changes everything. That means it's not equivalent to `nil` all in that case. OK, thanks for the help.

Curiously the tests explode if I try to defer require the modules under `func` or `filetype`. Unsure why though.

Log: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/7714525163/job/21026982521?pr=27216
I'm feeling pretty pleased with this. Any comments/reviews before merging?

title: refactor: create function for deferred loading
